column1: Keelung (Mandarin pinyin: Jīlóng; Hokkien POJ: Ke-lâng)
column3: is a major port city situated in the northeastern part of Taiwan. It borders New Taipei with which it forms the Taipei–Keelung metropolitan area
column4: along with Taipei itself. Nicknamed the Rainy Port for its frequent rain and maritime role
column5: the city is Taiwan's second largest seaport (after Kaohsiung).

column2: this northern coastal area was originally called Pak-kang (Chinese: 北港; Pe̍h-ōe-jī: Pak-káng). By the early 20th century
column3: the city was known to the Western world as Kelung
column4: as well as the variants Kiloung
column5: Kilang and Keelung. In his 1903 general history of Taiwan
column6: US Consul to Formosa (1898–1904) James W. Davidson related that "Kelung" was among the few well-known names
column7: thus warranting no alternate Japanese romanization.However
column8: the Taiwanese people have long called the city Kelang (Chinese: 雞籠; Pe̍h-ōe-jī: Ke-lâng/Koe-lâng; lit.: '“rooster cage"
column9: "hencoop” or “chicken coop”'). While it has been proposed that this name was derived from the local mountain that took the shape of a rooster cage
column10: it is more likely that the name was derived from the first inhabitants of the region
column11: as are the names of many other Taiwanese cities. In this case
column12: the Ketagalan people were the first inhabitants
column13: and early Han settlers probably approximated "Ketagalan" with Ke-lâng (Hokkien phonetics).

column1: Keelung was first inhabited by the Ketagalan
column2: a tribe of Taiwanese aborigine. The Spanish expedition to Formosa in the early 17th century was its first contact with the West; by 1624 the Spanish had built San Salvador de Quelung
column3: a fort in Keelung serving as an outpost of the Manila-based Spanish East Indies. The Spanish ruled it as a part of Spanish Formosa. From 1642 to 1661 and 1663–1668
column4: Keelung was under Dutch control. The Dutch East India Company took over the Spanish Fort San Salvador at Santissima Trinidad. They reduced its size and renamed it Fort Noort-Hollant. The Dutch had three more minor fortifications in Keelung and also a little school and a preacher.

column1: When Ming Dynasty loyalist Koxinga successfully attacked the Dutch in southern Taiwan

column2: the crew of the Keelung forts fled to the Dutch trading post in Japan. The Dutch came back in 1663 and re-occupied and strengthened their earlier forts. However
column3: trade with Qing China through Keelung was not what they hoped it would be and
column5: they left after getting harassed by aboriginals.

column1: Given the strategic and commercial value of Taiwan
column2: there were British suggestions in 1840 and 1841 to seize the island. In September 1841
column3: during the First Opium War
column4: the British transport ship Nerbudda became shipwrecked near Keelung Harbour due to a typhoon. The brig Ann also became shipwrecked in March 1842. Most of the crew were Indian lascars. Survivors from both ships were transferred by authorities to the capital Tainan. The Taiwan Qing commanders
column6: filed a disingenuous report to the emperor
column7: claiming to have defended against an attack from the Keelung fort. In October 1841
column8: HMS Nimrod sailed to Keelung to search for the Nerbudda survivors
column9: but after Captain Joseph Pearse found out that they were sent south for imprisonment
column10: he ordered the bombardment of the harbour and destroyed 27 sets of cannon before returning to Hong Kong. Most of the survivors—over 130 from the Nerbudda and 54 from the Ann—were executed in Tainan in August 1842.In 1863
column11: the Qing Empire opened up Keelung as a trading port and the city enjoyed rapid development due to the abundant commodities such as placer gold and high quality coal found in the drainage area of Keelung River. In 1875
column12: Taipeh Prefecture was created and included Keelung. In 1878
column13: Keelung was formed into a ting or sub-prefecture. Around the same time
column14: the name was changed from Ke-lang (雞籠廳) to Kilong (基隆廳)

column2: the French attempted an invasion of Taiwan during the Keelung Campaign. Liu Mingchuan
column3: who led the defence of Taiwan
column4: recruited Aboriginals to serve alongside the Chinese soldiers in fighting against the French of Colonel Jacques Duchesne's Formosa Expeditionary Corps. The French were defeated at the Battle of Tamsui and the Qing forces pinned the French down at Keelung in an eight-month-long campaign before the French withdrew.

column1: A systematic city development started during the Japanese Era
column3: which handed all Taiwan over to Japan. A five-phase construction of Keelung Harbor was initiated
column4: and in by 1916 trade volume had exceeded even those of Tamsui and Kaohsiung Harbors to become one of the major commercial harbors of Taiwan.Keelung was governed as Kīrun town (基隆街)
column6: Taihoku Prefecture in 1920 and was upgraded to a city in 1924. The Pacific War broke out in 1941
column7: and Keelung became one of the first targets of Allied bombers and was nearly destroyed as a result.

column1: After the handover of Taiwan from Japan to the Republic of China in October 1945
column2: Keelung was established as a provincial city of Taiwan Province. The Keelung City Government worked with the harbor bureau to rebuild the city and the harbor and in 1984
column3: the harbor became the 7th largest container harbor in the world.

column1: Keelung City is located in the northern part of Taiwan Island. It occupies an area of 132.76 km2 (51.26 sq mi) and is separated from its neighboring county by mountains in the east
column2: west and south. The northern part of the city faces the ocean and is a great deep water harbor since early times. Keelung also administers the nearby Keelung Islet as well as the more distant and strategically important Pengjia Islet
column3: Mianhua Islet and Huaping Islet.

column1: Keelung has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) with a yearly rainfall average upwards of 3
column2: 700 millimetres (146 in). It has long been noted as one of the wettest and gloomiest cities in the world; the effect is related to the Kuroshio Current. Although it is one of the coolest cities of Taiwan
column3: winters are still short and warm
column6: temperatures can peek above 26 °C during a warm winter day
column7: while it can dip below 27 °C during a rainy summer day
column8: much like the rest of northern Taiwan. However its location on northern mountain slopes means that due to orographic lift
column9: rainfall is heavier during fall and winter
column10: the latter during which a northeasterly flow prevails. During summer
column11: southwesterly winds dominate and thus there is a slight rain shadow effect. Fog is most serious during winter and spring
column12: when relative humidity levels are also highest.

column1: Zhongzheng District is the seat of Keelung City which houses the Keelung City Government and Keelung City Council. The current Mayor of Keelung is Lin Yu-chang of the Democratic Progressive Party.
Keelung City voted one Democratic Progressive Party legislator to be in the Legislative Yuan during the 2016 Republic of China legislative election.
One of the most popular festivals in Taiwan is the mid-summer Ghost Festival. The Keelung Ghost Festival is among the oldest in Taiwan
column2: dating back to 1851 after bitter clashes between rival clans
column3: which claimed many lives before mediators stepped in.

column1: Coal mining peaked in 1968. The city developed quickly and by 1984
column2: the harbor was the 7th largest container harbor in the world.

Keelung City houses several universities and colleges
